coredata.dc:description: In the field of photocatalysis, one focus is on high-performance visible light catalysis. For this study, which follows the defect engineering strategy, ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) S defect-rich MoS2 nanosheets were created in situ by ball-milling MoS2 nanosheets with ascorbic acid and then used for the removal of Cr(VI) from wastewater. The results show that ascorbic acid increases both the specific surface area of MoS2 nanosheets and the concentration of S stripping-defects significantly. Of the samples, D-MoS2-3 (i.e., S defect-rich ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets) exhibited the best Cr(VI) adsorption capacity and photocatalytic activity thanks to its large specific surface area and a high concentration of total S defects (18.5%), 311.1% better than for P-MoS2 (i.e., pristine MoS2 nanosheets) (4.5%). The concentration of S point-defects in D-MoS2-3 is only a little greater than in P-MoS2, but the concentration of S stripping-defects is significantly greater. S point-defects at such a high concentration readily act as recombination centers for photogenerated carriers. By contrast, S stripping-defects that lack dangling Mo-S bonds trap photogenerated holes and add to the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. As a consequence, the photocatalytic performance of D-MoS2-3 in removing Cr(VI) is significantly better. Given this finding, the present study offers a new design pathway and a reference for the practical application of defect engineering to ultrathin 2D materials.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: In the field of photocatalysis, one focus is on high-performance visible light catalysis. For this study, which follows the defect engineering strategy, ultrathin two-dimensional (2D) S defect-rich MoS2 nanosheets were created in situ by ball-milling MoS2 nanosheets with ascorbic acid and then used for the removal of Cr(VI) from wastewater. The results show that ascorbic acid increases both the specific surface area of MoS2 nanosheets and the concentration of S stripping-defects significantly. Of the samples, D-MoS2-3 (i.e., S defect-rich ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets) exhibited the best Cr(VI) adsorption capacity and photocatalytic activity thanks to its large specific surface area and a high concentration of total S defects (18.5%), 311.1% better than for P-MoS2 (i.e., pristine MoS2 nanosheets) (4.5%). The concentration of S point-defects in D-MoS2-3 is only a little greater than in P-MoS2, but the concentration of S stripping-defects is significantly greater. S point-defects at such a high concentration readily act as recombination centers for photogenerated carriers. By contrast, S stripping-defects that lack dangling Mo-S bonds trap photogenerated holes and add to the separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. As a consequence, the photocatalytic performance of D-MoS2-3 in removing Cr(VI) is significantly better. Given this finding, the present study offers a new design pathway and a reference for the practical application of defect engineering to ultrathin 2D materials.

ce:section.ce:para: Due to accelerating industrialization worldwide and the expanding scope of human activities, the global environment and human health are increasingly threatened by pollution from the heavy metal, chromium (Cr). Cr-containing wastewater is produced by the electroplating, tanning, metal processing and chromium salt industries [1â3]. There are two valence states for Cr ions in water. One is highly water-soluble and mobile hexavalent chromium (Cr(VI)), a carcinogen II on the World Health Organizationâs list that takes the form of Cr2O7 2- or CrO4 2-. The other valence state is less toxic and less mobile trivalent chromium (Cr(III)), which takes the form of the precipitate, Cr(OH)3 [4,5]. This means conversion of Cr(VI) to Cr(III), which then precipitates out, will reduce the harmful impact of Cr(VI) on the general environment and living organisms [6,7].

Currently, much effort [6â11] is being dedicated to reducing the toxicity of wastewater that contains Cr(VI), using chemical, electrochemical and biological reduction. Each of these methods, however, has its disadvantages, such as high cost, poor circulation, high energy consumption and secondary pollution [12]. Because of their low cost, easy operation and lack of polluting byproducts, photocatalytic methods have attracted increasing attention in pollution control circles. Their future use, however, hinges on the development of high-performance photocatalysts with a wide spectral response range, high electron transport efficiency, and a low recombination rate for photogenerated electron-hole pairs [13,14]. Therefore, the creation of visible-light catalysts meeting these criteria has been a hotspot for environmental pollution treatment research.

In this effort, candidate photocatalysts such as metal oxides (TiO2 [15,16], ZnO [17,18]), metal sulfides (CuS [19,20], MoS2 [21,22]), and perovskite composite oxides (BaTiO3 [23], SrFe0.5Ta0.5O3 [24]), have all inspired investigation. Unfortunately, to some degree they also all exhibit flaws like poor utilization of visible light, difficulty in recycling, harsh preparation conditions and high cost. Research on ultrathin 2D nano-photocatalysts like the target of this study began in 2004, when Andre Geim [25] and Konstantin Novoselov successfully prepared graphene through micromechanical exfoliation. In the following decade, a succession of similar 2D materials appeared, including transition-metal chalcogenides (TMDs), layered metal oxides, MXenes, bismuth-based materials and layered double metal oxides (LDHs) [26â30]. Of these, molybdenum disulfide (MoS2), a transition-metal chalcogenide, has emerged as the most promising photocatalyst, thanks to its easy availability and its adjustable band gap, which is dependent on the number of layers. It is common to use MoS2 as a co-catalyst with other photocatalysts to form a heterojunction structure, such as RP-MoS2/rGO [31], CNT@MoS2/SnS2 [32] and CeO2-MoS2 composites [33]. However, such a combination makes poor use of the advantages of the ultrathin 2D microstructure of MoS2. Indeed, the introduction of an exogenous heterogeneous photocatalyst causes occupation of active sites and poor interface electron transport efficiency in the heterojunction structure, which prevents the improvement of photocatalytic efficiency.

There are relatively fewer studies of using MoS2 alone as a photocatalyst for energy conversion and environmental pollution treatment. Due to the hexagonal structure of MoS2, the S-Mo-S covalent bonds in each layer are relatively stable, and the layers themselves are easy to peel away because the van der Waals forces are fairly weak. The thermodynamically stable phase, 2H-MoS2, suffers from limited charge transfer efficiency and a high recombination rate of the photogenerated carriers, due to a lack of electrons at the reaction interface. This hampers its use and development. Many strategies, such as surface modification and functionalization [34,35], doping [36,37] and defect engineering [38â40], are applied to achieve effective reduction of these limiting factors. Among them, defect engineering has attracted the most attention, focusing on either exposed edges or basal plane defects, the two types of active catalytic centers in ultrathin 2D MoS2. One approach relies on various strategies for synthesizing a form of MoS2 nanocrystalline with more exposed active edges, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. The results include hollow nanostructures [41], double gyroscope structures [42], nanotubes [43] and flower-like shapes [44]. Experiments and calculations have demonstrated that the atom-saturated basal plane is chemically inert due to its poor bulk conduction and anisotropic electrical transport on the MoS2 surface [45â48]. The other effective approach is introducing active defects on the inert basal plane itself. In 2016, using argon (Ar) plasma, Li [49] introduced S vacancies into the MoS2 basal plane for the first time, thereby activating it. More and more techniques for activating the MoS2 basal plane have since been studied, including chemical etching [50,51], plasma etching [52], heteroatom doping [53] and ball-milling [54,55]. Chemical etching and heteroatom doping require complicated operations, however, and the yield is low. The experimental conditions required for plasma etching are more than ordinary laboratories can achieve. This leaves ball-milling as the approach of choice. Normally, the adsorption performance of MoS2 plays a dominant role in the photoreduction of Cr(VI) [56,57], with the photocatalytic rate being proportional to the number of reactive active sites. In addition, the larger the specific surface area, the more photocatalytic active sites there will be. Ball-milling introduces disorder and defects into the atomic structure of MoS2 while also shearing the nanosheets longitudinally and transversely. The operation is simple enough that mass production is possible. Defective MoS2 nanosheets had already been created by ball-milling [54] or a combination of ball-milling and ultrasonic treatment [55], but these studies used a special ball milling device in an inert atmosphere. They also did not delve deeply into the influence of defect-type and distribution on the eventual photocatalytic performance of the material. It is of great practical importance, however, to find an easier way to create defective ultrathin 2D MoS2, and to analyze the mechanism by which the distribution of defects influences its photocatalytic performance. Success in these regards could promote the development and use of 2D materials in the field of environmental decontamination.

For this study, S defect-rich ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets were created in situ by ball-milling in an organic acid reducing agent system, and the nanosheets were thinned and broken up. The resulting S defect-rich ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets were used to photo-reduce Cr(VI). In addition, the existence and distribution of the defects and their role in the materialâs photocatalytic performance were all analyzed in detail.

Molybdenum trioxide (MoO3, â¥99.95%) was purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biotechnology Co., Ltd. Sublimated sulfur (S, â¥99.5%), isopropanol (IPA), ethanol (EA) and sodium sulfate (Na2SO4) were purchased from Chengdu Kelong Chemical Co., Ltd. P-benzoquinone (BQ) was obtained from Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd. Ascorbic acid (C6H8O6) was purchased from Chengdu Jinshan Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd. As a target pollutant, potassium dichromate (K2Cr2O7, â¥ 99.5%) was purchased from Chengdu United Chemical Reagent Research Institute. The above reagents were all of analytical grade, and used without further purification. Aqueous solutions were prepared using laboratory-made deionized water.

MoS2 nanosheets were prepared using the classic solid phase microdomain method [58], with adjustment of some parameters for this study (as shown in Fig. S1-S3 and Table S1-S4). First, MoO3 (0.38 g) and S powder (0.50 g) were ball-milled for 24 h at a ball/sample weight ratio of 45: 1 in a planetary ball mill at 580 rpm minâ1 under an air atmosphere. The treated mixture was then annealed at 600 Â°C under a nitrogen (N2) atmosphere for 2 h. The furnace was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature, producing the original, pristine MoS2 nanosheets used in this study, labeled P-MoS2.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Fabrication of S defect-rich ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets
ce:section.ce:para: The S defect-rich ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets were created using a swift ball-milling method. First, ascorbic acid was mixed with four separate samples of P-MoS2, each weighing 0.50 g, at molar ratios of P-MoS2 to ascorbic acid of 1: 0, 4: 1, 2: 1, and 1: 1, respectively. These four mixtures were then ball-milled at 580 rpm for 1 h at a ball/sample weight ratio of 45: 1. The mixtures were next washed with 100 mL of deionized water, followed by ultrasound for 1 h. The mixtures were then washed six times with deionized water, centrifuged, and finally freeze-dried. The results were MoS2 with different defect concentrations, labeled BM-MoS2, D-MoS2-1, D-MoS2-2 and D-MoS2-3, respectively.

20.00 mg of the photocatalyst were added into 50.00 mL potassium dichromate standard solution (20.00 mg Lâ1 Cr(VI), C
0 ) at a pH of 5.0. Prior to irradiation, each aqueous suspension was mixed by ultrasound for 5 min in the dark to reach adsorption equilibrium. The aqueous suspension was then irradiated with a 32 W visible light (Xe lamp, Î» â¥ 420 nm, illumination 5.00 mW cmâ2). 1.50 mL of the aqueous suspension was sucked out at regular intervals and filtered using a water-based filter (0.22 Âµm) in order to measure the diminishing concentration of Cr(VI) (C). 1.00 mL of the supernatant was analyzed using the 1, 5-diphenylcarbazide (DPCI) method to determine the Cr(VI) concentration as measured by a UV4802H spectrophotometer (Î»
max = 540 nm) using the standard curve of Cr(VI). The efficiency of removal of Cr(VI) was calculated using Eq. (1):
(1) Removal efficiency = (1 - C/ C
0 )

Additionally, in order to understand the mechanism of the photocatalytic removal of Cr(VI), ethanol (EA), potassium bromate (KBrO3), isopropanol (IPA), and p-benzoquinone (BQ) solutions, as well as a certain flow of N2, were all applied to scavenge holes (h+), electrons (e-), hydroxide radicals (â¢OH), superoxide radicals (â¢O2 -), and oxygen (O2), respectively, in the photocatalytic system [59â62]. The same volume (0.25 mL) and concentration (0.5 mM) of the above agents for trapping active groups were added after the ultrasonic adsorption equilibrium of 15.00 mg photocatalyst in 50 mL potassium dichromate standard solution (20.00 mg Lâ1, Cr(VI)) was reached. The adsorption and photocatalytic capacities of the sample were calculated based on the absorbance of the suspension after ultrasound and photocatalysis for 3 h.

The crystal structure and crystallinity of the samples as produced were identified using an X-ray diffractometer (XRD, PANalytical X Pert pro) equipped with Cu KÎ± radiation. The morphology of the materials was determined using high-resolution images obtained by field emission transmission electron microscopy (TEM, Carl Zeiss Irts Libra 200FE). The thickness of the samples was measured by a scanning probe microscope (AFM, NSK SPA-300HV). STEM images were taken on a Titan Cubed Themis G2 300 TEM operated at 300 kV, and the attainable resolution of the probe as defined by the objective prefield was 60 picometers. The specific surface area (BET) was measured using a NOVA 3000 specific surface and porosity analyzer. X-ray photoemission spectroscopy (XPS) was done with a Thermo Scientific ESCALAB Xi+ system. Electron paramagnetic resonance spectrometry (EPR) was done on 0.20 g of each sample using a Bruker EMX micro 9.5/12 spectrometer at room temperature. The structure of the sample molecules was analyzed using the inVia laser Raman spectrometer equipped with a 785 nm laser. Photoluminescence spectroscopy (PL) was done using a Hitachi F-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer. The absorbance values of the powders were determined using a Shimadzu Solidspec-3700 solid-state ultraviolet absorption spectrometer. The photoelectrochemical performance of the samples was measured on the Shanghai Chenhua CHI660E electrochemical work station under a Xe lamp at an illumination density of 100 mW cmâ2. For work electrode preparation, 8 mg photocatalyst powder and 10 ÂµL nafion membrane solution were first dispersed in 240 ÂµL of ethylene glycol and treated with ultrasound for 30 min to form a homogeneous ink. The ink was then dripped onto the FTO glass over an area of about 1.0 Ã 1.0 cm2. Finally, the ink-coated FTO glass sheet was dried in an oven at 60 Â°C for 6 h.

Fig. 1(a) shows the XRD patterns of the samples. The characteristic diffraction peaks at 14.3Â°, 33.1Â°, 39.7Â°, 49.6Â° and 58.5Â° are indexed to the (002), (100), (103), (105) and (110) crystal planes of 2H-MoS2 (JCPDS No. 37-1492), respectively. The shape of the diffraction peaks of all samples remained basically unchanged, and crystallinity fitted by Jade software showed no significant change either (Fig. 1b), indicating that the microstructure of the samples was well preserved. According to related reports [55,63], the stacking layer of MoS2 crystal along the c-axis is (002) crystal plane direction. Based on the Scherrer formula, the number of layers can be calculated semi-quantitatively. And the gradually widening FWHM (the full width at half maximum of signal) of the diffraction peak of the (002) crystal plane proves that the stacking number of MoS2 was significantly reduced, from approximately 9 layers to 5 layers (Table S5), due to the addition of ascorbic acid. Moreover, the diffraction peak of the broadening (110) crystal plane is related to the shrinking base plane size [63]. The specific surface areas of the photocatalysts are estimated at 60.1, 64.7, 72.1, 109.4 and 151.7 m2 gâ1 for P-MoS2, BM-MoS2, D-MoS2-1, D-MoS2-2 and D-MoS2-3, respectively (Fig. 1c). The particle size of the D-MoS2-3 nanosheets is smaller and the specific surface area has increased by nearly 150% than after processing, which is consistent with the results of the XRD analysis.

In addition, the pore size distributions of these samples were obtained using the BJH model. The results are shown in the inset in Fig. 1(c). The pore volumes of P-MoS2, BM-MoS2, D-MoS2-1, D-MoS2-2 and D-MoS2-3 are 0.356, 0.038, 0.217, 0.256 and 0.429 cc gâ1, respectively. After ball milling, the pore volume of MoS2 decreased sharply, but the pore structure of MoS2 nanosheets was gradually restored and expanded when ascorbic acid was added, probably accounting for the increased adsorption capacity and photocatalytic activity. These results confirm that the ascorbic acid thins and fragments MoS2 nanosheets. In addition, the characteristic peaks of 1756 and 1670âcmâ1 for ascorbic acid in the FT-IR spectra are a product of the stretching vibrations of CO and CC, respectively. (Fig. 1d) [64]. The fact that MoS2 did not show similar vibration absorption peaks at the same locations means that it contained no residual ascorbic acid.

The TEM images and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images revealed the morphologies of the samples. Fig. 2(a) shows that P-MoS2 is in nanosheets about 100ânm long. As Fig. 2(b) shows, the regular lattice fringes at a spacing of 6.2âÃ corresponding to the (002) planes of 2âH-MoS2, indicate that P-MoS2 is a 2âH-MoS2 nanosheet with higher crystallinity and a relatively intact layered structure. Fig. 2(d) shows that D-MoS2-3 is a nano-fragment with a smaller particle size. This high-resolution field shows defects in the structure of the D-MoS2-3, typically consisting of cracks and misaligned basal planes, as previously observed in the literature (Fig. 2e) [65â67]. Fig. 2(c) shows that the stacking height of P-MoS2 is about 7.7ânm, or about 12 layers. The area of D-MoS2-3 is smaller, but its stacking height is only 1.8ânm, or about 3 layers (Fig. 2f). These results show that ascorbic acid can effectively fragment and thin MoS2, which is in agreement with the XRD results.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Distribution and structural evolution of defects
ce:section.ce:para: The above analysis demonstrates that as-prepared ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets have abundant defects. In order to ascertain the form, distribution and proportions of their surface defects, the samples were further characterized by XPS, Raman and EPR. As Fig. 3(a) shows, two characteristic peaks of P-MoS2, at 229.5 and 232.7âeV, can be attributed to Mo4+ 3d5/2 and Mo4+ 3d3/2, respectively. The peak at 226.6âeV corresponds to the S 2s orbital of MoS2. In the S 2p spectrum (Fig. 3b), the peaks at 162.3 and 163.5âeV correspond to S 2p3/2 and S 2p1/2. Compared to P-MoS2, the binding energy of the characteristic peak of BM-MoS2 increases by 0.3âeV in the Mo 3d and S 2p spectra, but the intensity of the peak is almost unchanged. This may result from the extra tension in the disordered lattice [54], leading to Mo and S electron delocalization and a consequent decrease of electron cloud density outside the nucleus, and therefore a higher binding energy. Compared to BM-MoS2, the binding energy of the characteristic peak of D-MoS2-3 is 0.25âeV less, and the intensity is obviously weaker, indicating that defects have been introduced into the MoS2 nanosheets [53,67]. There is an obvious new peak at 169.2âeV with a low intensity attributed to S6+ in the S 2p spectrum of D-MoS2-3, indicating that a bit of S2- was oxidized to S6+. The reason for this is that S2- in superfine powder exposed to the humidity in air produces SO4 2- [68â70]. Most significantly, the normalized S/Mo stoichiometric ratio drops from 1.9 for P-MoS2 to 1.6 for D-MoS2-3, as shown in Table S6. The loss of sulfur atoms suggests that the total percentage of S defects has increased from 4.5% to 18.5%. As Fig. S4 shows, the normalized O atomic percentage of D-MoS2-3 (5.1%) is close to that in P-MoS2 (7.1%), proving that O atoms are not occupying the S defect sites.

Raman spectroscopy can assess the effect of lattice strain, the van der Waals interaction at the interface of 2D MoS2, in terms of the position and intensity of two characteristic vibrational modes, E1 2âg and A1âg [71]. According to Fig. 3(d), P-MoS2 shows these modes, at 378.0âcmâ1 and 403.8âcmâ1, which are related to E1 2âg, the in-plane vibration mode of S atoms, and A1âg, the out-of-plane vibration mode of the Mo-S bond, respectively. Compared to P-MoS2, both the vibration modes E1 2âg and A1âg of BM-MoS2 show a blue-shift toward higher wavenumbers that can be ascribed to the distortion of the MoS2 nanostructure from ball milling [72]. The addition of ascorbic acid causes the E1 2âg and A1âg vibration modes of the specimens (D-MoS2-1, D-MoS2-2, D-MoS2-3) to experience a gradual red-shift toward lower wavenumbers. Eventually, in the presence of a sufficiently amount of ascorbic acid, the E1 2âg vibration modes of D-MoS2-3 became weaker and wider, which reflects the presence of abundant defects in the basal plane of 2D MoS2 [73]. The intensity of the A1âg vibration mode decreases, indicating a weakening of the interlayer force and the fact that ascorbic acid can peel away the layers of MoS2.

The EPR measurements can serve to semi-quantitatively characterize the number of unpaired electrons on the coordinated unsaturated defect sites in order to verify the existence of S vacancies and calculate their relative concentration. As Fig. 3(e) shows, all specimens had a response signal of Mo-S dangling bonds at g =â2.003, which confirms that the S vacancies exist in each sample [74]. Unexpectedly, the S vacancy signal intensity of BM-MoS2 is the strongest, while the S vacancy signal strength of D-MoS2-1, D-MoS2-2, D-MoS2-3 is successively less. According to EPR principles, the EPR signal for MoS2 indicates a single vacancy with Mo-S dangling bonds, while the XPS results reflect the overall concentration of defects. This demonstrates that the single vacancy number of BM-MoS2 is the highest for the samples, but D-MoS2-3 has the most defects over all. Moreover, in accord with what has already been reported in the literature [67,75], when the S/Mo atomic ratio exceeds 1.7, the samples in this study contain many S point-defects related to EPR signals, but when the S/Mo atomic ratio is less than 1.7, S stripping-defects with a lower Mo coordination number appear on the basal plane of the sample. These results show that ascorbic acid is very effective at generating S stripping-defects. The normalized S/Mo atomic ratio of commercial thin MoS2 is 1.76 (Table. S7). As Fig. S5 shows, the binding energy of commercial MoS2 is about 0.4âeV lower than for P-MoS2 and D-MoS2-3, which is due to the shielding effect of electrons liberated by a large number of S point-defects [50]. Consequently, the ratio of the two types of defects was adjusted to be more conducive to the desired photocatalytic reaction.

In order to make the S stripping- and point-defects visible to the eye, the samples were characterized using spherical aberration correction transmission electron microscopy ( Fig. 4). Thanks to the difference in contrast intensity and in the size of Mo spots in the STEM images, one can see the S point- and aggregate-vacancies in the basal plane of MoS2 [50]. As Fig. 4(b) shows, in P-MoS2 most of the Mo spots are in a regular arrangement, and there are only a few places where the Mo atom contrast is dimmer and the Mo spot is smaller, revealing the existence of S point-defects in the basal plane of P-MoS2. As Fig. 4(d) shows, in D-MoS2-3 there are areas of disorder in the array of Mo atoms, and larger areas of dimmer and smaller Mo spots, due to the presence of precisely the S stripping-defects that this study propounds.

The structural evolution of ultrathin 2D MoS2 rich in S defects can be visualized by combining the EPR and XPS results, as shown in Fig. 5. The blue area in Fig. 5 shows that the 2H-MoS2 annealed at 600âÂ°C in a nitrogen atmosphere has a relatively intact atomic structure, but the unsaturation coordination number of Mo atoms of MoS2 increases after ball-milling with ascorbic acid. At the same time, S point-defects and S stripping-defects coexist as shown in the green region of the graphic.

The foregoing discussion shows that ball-milling with ascorbic acid generates both S point-defects and S stripping-defects in MoS2 nanosheets and that adjustments to the amount of ascorbic acid can serve to regulate the concentration of both types of defects. The next step is to investigate the effect of these defects on the photocatalytic reduction performance regarding Cr(VI).

The Zeta potential of the samples (Table S8) indicates that the surface of MoS2, due to electrostatic attraction, favors the uptake of the Cr(III) at the initial pH, a phenomenon that will interfere to some degree with the photocatalytic reaction to some degree. Preferential adsorption at and occupation of active sites affect photocatalytic performance, which in turn plays a decisive role in the overall Cr(VI) removal rate. Fig. 6(a) shows that the ability of the samples to adsorb Cr(VI)-containing ions gradually increases in tandem with the size of the specific surface area. For instance, the photocatalytic activity of P-MoS2 is only 21.0% in visible light, but D-MoS2-3 achieved a 98.9% reduction of Cr(VI) within 180âmin. When the normalized first-order kinetic fitting constant (Fig. 6c) is used to eliminate the influence of specific surface area on the photoreduction rate, one finds that the normalized apparent rate constant of photoreduction for D-MoS2-3 (5.1âÃ10â7 minâ1 cmâ2) is actually about 15.4 times higher than that for P-MoS2 (3.3âÃâ10â8 minâ1 cmâ2). Compared with reported MoS2-based catalysts (Table S9), the D-MoS2-3 created for this study is a highly active photocatalytic reducer of Cr(VI), making it a promising candidate for practical applications [21,31â34,57,76â79]. In addition, D-MoS2-3, which (as Fig. 6d shows) has the highest removal rate and highest photoreduction activity with regard to Cr(VI), maintains a removal rate of about 95.0% even after four consecutive cycles of adsorptions and photocatalysis, indicating that its adsorption and photocatalytic performance is eminently stable.

In Fig. 7(a), the high resolution Cr 2p spectrum of the D-MoS2-3 after photoreduction has two characteristic peaks with binding energies of 577.7 and 587.5âeV, which can be assigned to Cr 2p3/2 and Cr 2p1/2 of Cr(III) [57], respectively. This confirms that the less toxic form of chromium, Cr(III), converted from the more toxic form, Cr(VI), covers the surface of the photocatalyst after photoreduction [76]. In order to distinguish between the effects of adsorption and the effects of photocatalysis, the concentration of Cr(VI) in the dark or light (Fig. S6) were investigated, and the results showed that the photocatalyst basically reached the saturated adsorption within 5âmin. Cr 2p spectra of D-MoS2-3 that adsorbed Cr(VI) in the absence of light were obtained at the same time. The binding energy of response peaks were at 578.7 and 588.4âeV, corresponding to Cr 2p3/2 and Cr 2p1/2 [80], and further indicating adsorption of Cr(VI) without reduction. Obviously, it is desirable for a photocatalyst to remain stable as long as possible. The fact that (as Fig. 7b shows) the crystal structure of D-MoS2-3 remains almost unchanged after photocatalysis indicates that the as-prepared photocatalyst has the desired high stability. The XPS spectra also show that the intensity and shape of the peaks remain unchanged after photocatalysis, indicating that the defect structure of D-MoS2-3 after photocatalysis remains relatively complete [54] (as Fig. 7câd demonstrate). In Mo 3d and S 2p spectra, all these characteristic peaks have shifted 0.37âeV toward a lower binding energy. This may arise from the increase of electron cloud density outside the nucleus due to the delocalization of electrons generated by a small amount of Cr(III) on the surface of the sample after the reaction [81]. Meanwhile, the normalized S/Mo stoichiometric ratio of the sample remains at 1.6 (Table S10).

As Fig. S7 shows, the lower the pH of the solution, the greater the photocatalytic ability of the photocatalyst as well as its ability to adsorb for Cr(VI). Indeed, at a pH of 1.0, D-MoS2-3 removes 50âmgâLâ1 of Cr(VI) within 3âh. As one knows, the potential of Cr2O7 2-/Cr3+ changes with pH. The lower the pH value is, the stronger the oxidation ability of Cr(VI) is. In addition, since the surface charge of MoS2 varies significantly with the pH [56], D-MoS2-3 has stronger electrostatic force and thermodynamic driving force at lower pH, thus it has better adsorption and photocatalysis performance of Cr(VI). At the pH of 7.0 and 9.0, the adsorption capacity and the photoreduction activity of D-MoS2-3 to Cr2O7 2- got weak obviously. According to the solubility product of Cr(OH)3, Cr(III) begins to precipitate at the pH of 6.0 [82]. When the pH was higher than this value, the photocatalytic product Cr(III) would precipitate, which hindered the photocatalytic progress.

Based on the aforesaid experimental results, we did a series of measurements to explore the mechanism of S defect-rich 2D MoS2 photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI). To clarify the photo-response charge transfer characteristics and interface reaction resistance of the photocatalyst, the transient photocurrent response and electrochemical impedance test values were measured on the electrochemical work station in a 50âs interval switch cycle test under simulated sunlight of 100âmWâcmâ2 ( Fig. 8a). The photocurrent density of D-MoS2-3 is about 3.4 times that of P-MoS2 and 3.1 times that of BM-MoS2, respectively, indicating that the introduction of S defects enhances photocurrent. In addition, compared to the other photocatalysts, the Nyquist plot for the D-MoS2-3 has the smallest radius (Fig. 8b). The equivalent circuit diagram (the small inset in Fig. 8b) was generated using ZSimpWin fitting software, where R
s represents the electrolyte resistance, C is the double-layer capacitor, Q
dl is the constant phase component related to the double-layer capacitor, and R
ct1 and R
ct2 are the electron transfer resistances in the electrolyte. The fitting results show that, the impedance of materials significantly decreases from 38.0âÎ© for P-MoS2 to 11.2âÎ© for D-MoS2-3 as the amount of ascorbic acid added to the initial mixtures increases. This proves that the existence of S defects promotes the separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs. The larger number of retained carriers in turn promotes interface charge transfer and accelerates photocatalysis.

The logical next step was to measure the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers in S defect-rich 2D MoS2 nanosheets using photoluminescence spectroscopy at room temperature. Fig. 8(c) gives the PL spectra for the samples in the wavelength range of 560â800ânm under excitation by light with a 265ânm wavelength. These spectra have similar outlines but different intensities. The broadband emission spectrum for P-MoS2 centers at 604ânm, which can be attributed to the intrinsic direct bandgap transition of MoS2 [83]. Somewhat unexpectedly, BM-MoS2 has the strongest emission intensity, indicating that it has the strongest photogenerated carrier recombination ability. The reason for the enhancement of the fluorescent intensity of BM-MoS2 as compared with P-MoS2 may be the reduction in the number of stacking layers and the large amount of S point-defect [84,85]. In the presence of ascorbic acid, however, the layer number of D-MoS2-3 is even smaller than that of BM-MoS2, and the fluorescent intensity is much weaker. This implies that the introduction of S stripping-defects in D-MoS2-3 will hinder the recombination of photogenerated carriers. As the amount of ascorbic acid in the initial mixtures increases, not only does the intensity of the PL spectra of the photocatalysts gradually decrease, but the central point gradually shifts to 594ânm. In addition, the introduction of S defects and the modification of defect types enlarge the semiconductor band gap from 2.05âeV for P-MoS2 to 2.09âeV for D-MoS2-3 [86]. This shows that, increasing the concentration of S stripping-defects tends to inhibit the recombination of photogenerated carriers. In addition, the solid-state ultraviolet absorption spectra (Fig. 8d) show that the absorbance value of the samples is inversely proportional to the PL intensity values. In other words, D-MoS2-3, which has the highest overall defect concentration, also has the highest absorbance. A lower recombination rate of photogenerated carriers is one of the reasons why D-MoS2-3 has the best photocatalytic performance, and its stronger light absorption in the visible light region is another reason for its superiority.

To ascertain the active species during photoreduction of Cr(VI) using D-MoS2-3 under visible light, we did free radical capture experiments. The high selectivity of free radicals allows one to analyze photocatalytic mechanism in finer detail. Fig. 9(a) shows that the adsorption ratio of Cr(VI) on D-MoS2-3 in the presence of different radical scavengers stayed at about 63.0%, but the photocatalytic ratio underwent various changes. In the presence of KBrO3, IPA and BQ, the photocatalytic ratio significantly decreases, from 23.8% to 18.6%, 18.6% and 18.1%, respectively, which means that the photogenerated electrons associated with â¢O2 - play an important role in the photoreduction of Cr(VI). By contrast, the photocatalytic ratio increases to 26.6% in the presence of EA. Thus, EA apparently acts to improves the separation efficiency of photogenerated carriers, while also demonstrating that the photogenerated electrons are one of the main active species. Once O2 is removed from the system, the photocatalytic ratio increases even further, to 27.7%. The dissolved oxygen in the system may come from the oxidation of H2O by photogenerated holes. If so, the removal of O2 will promote the oxidation of the water and facilitate the separation of the photogenerated hole-electron pairs, thereby improving the photocatalytic performance [87]. The dissolved oxygen in the water consumes most of the photogenerated electrons, generating â¢O2 -, and â¢O2 - will continue to oxidize H2O molecules to generate â¢OH. Due to â¢OH also being produced by photogenerated holes and then oxidizing H2O, the capture of â¢OH brings about both the consumption of photogenerated holes, and also the consumption of â¢O2 -. This may account for the phenomenon that once â¢OH has been trapped, photocatalytic reduction is partially inhibited. As Fig. 9(b) shows, the two kinds of response signal are greatly enhanced after the irradiation for 3âmin. The g factors at 2.014, 2.007, 1.999 and 1.991 are the typical signals of DMPO-â¢O2 -, while the peaks at 2.016, 2.006, 1.997 and 1.988 are the characteristic of DMPO-â¢OH [88]. Along with the results of the free radical capture experiments, this confirms that e- and â¢O2 - are the main active groups for photoreduction of Cr(VI). In addition, no H2O2 or 1O2 was detected during the entire photocatalysis process using D-MoS2-3 (Fig. S8).

At the same time, the Mott-Schottky results (Fig. S9) show that, the conductive band of the sample becomes increasingly negative as the amount of ascorbic acid increases, which indicates that the reducing ability of the sample also gradually increases. Table S11 shows the conduction band (CB), the valence band (VB) and bandgap (E
g ) for the samples. Photogenerated electrons in the samples can reduce Cr(VI) adsorbed on the catalyst surface to Cr(III) because the CB potential is more negative than that of Cr(VI)/ Cr(III) (0.51âV vs. NHE) [89,90]. The XPS results also confirm this conclusion. The potential of O2/ â¢O2 - is ââ0.33âV vs. NHE [91]. Therefore, in addition to directly participating in the photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI), some of the photogenerated electrons also reduce O2 to â¢O2 -, which is chemically adsorbed on the surface and indirectly participates in the photocatalytic removal of Cr(VI) [92]. Since the potential of O2/ H2O is 1.23âV, the holes can oxidize H2O to O2 in the system [93,94]. We can infer that part of the O2 in the system comes from dissolved oxygen in solution, with the rest coming from oxidation of the water, and in addition that part of the photogenerated electrons on the surface of D-MoS2-3 serve to reduce Cr(VI) while another part is consumed by O2. This seems to mean that there is a competition in this case between two kinds of consumption of electrons. If the above inferences are correct, since the CBs of BM-MoS2 and P-MoS2 are 0.05âV and ââ0.24âV, respectively, and both are more positive than the potential of O2/ â¢O2 -, it would seem that the O2 in these two systems does not compete with Cr(VI) as a consumer of photogenerated electrons. In other words, the efficiency of their photoreduction efficiency of Cr(VI) should be higher than for the samples treated with ascorbic acid. But in fact, the photoreduction efficiency of both BM-MoS2 and P-MoS2 is extremely low, which indicates that the difference in the potentials is not the key factor.

The histogram of the normalized apparent photoreduction rate and S point-defect concentration (Fig. 9c) shows that a high concentration of S point-defects does not significantly improve photoreduction of Cr(VI). D-MoS2-3 has the highest concentration of total S defects (18.5%), but its concentration of S point-defects is far less than what is found in BM-MoS2. If one also considers Fig. 9(d), one will conclude that the S defects in D-MoS2-3 are mainly stripping-defects. In addition, the fact that D-MoS2-3 has the highest normalized photoreduction rate means that the photoreduction rate for Cr(VI) correlates positively with the concentration of S stripping-defects. Therefore, on the one hand, the S stripping-defects in the catalyst contribute greatly to the photoreduction of Cr(VI), but, on the other hand, a high concentration of the S point-defects readily triggers recombination of photogenerated carriers by trapping charge carriers, which has the effect of inhibiting photocatalysis [95].

Based on the above analysis and discussion, the probable photocatalytic mechanism for the results presented in this study may be represented by Eq. (2) through Eq. (7), below, with Fig. 10 providing a schematic of the same mechanism.
(2) MoS2âX+ hv âh+ + e-
(3) Cr2O7 2- + 14H+ + 6 e-â2Cr3+ + 7H2O
(4) 2H2O + 4h+â O2 + 4H+
(5) O2 + e- â â¢O2 -
(6) â¢O2 - + H2O â HO2â¢ + OH-
(7) HO2â¢ + H2O â â¢OH + H2O2

To sum up: ultrathin 2D MoS2 nanosheets rich in S defects prepared using a quick ball-milling method in the presence of an organic acid reducing agent (ascorbic acid) can be used for photocatalytic reduction of Cr(VI) in daylight. The optimized form of this photocatalyst not only has a Cr(VI) removal performance of 98.9% in 180âmin, but its normalized photoreduction rate is about 15 times higher than that of P-MoS2. The results show that S defects come in two forms, point- and stripping-defects. At a high concentration, S point-defects tend to become recombination centers for photogenerated carriers, while S stripping-defects serve as trapping centers for photogenerated holes, thereby promoting the separation of photogenerated carriers. Judicious adjustment of the ratio of point-defects and stripping-defects can greatly improve photocatalytic performance. These findings offer new ideas and references for the preparation of high-efficiency ultrathin 2D nano-photocatalysts using defect engineering design. In the future, it is desirable that methods for precisely controlling the preparation of specific defect types be developed by researchers following up on these findings; that the correlation between these various methods and photocatalytic performance be established; and that a complete and accurate explanation of the photocatalytic mechanism be determined.
